Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-10
 
Student job title:
     ON-SITE mPMT Electronics Analyst
 
Name of project:
     IWCD / Hyper-Kamiokande
 
Overview:
     Neutrino oscillations are the only experimentally verified observation
     of a process not described by the Standard Model of particle physics.
     Since their discovery in 1998 we have learnt a lot about the
     parameters that govern neutrino oscillations, but there are still many
     questions remaining. In particular, we still need to determine whether
     neutrino oscillations violate the charge-parity symmetry of the
     Standard Model, and so could potentially explain why we live in a
     matter-dominated universe.
    
     IWCD is the proposed intermediate detector for the Hyper-Kamiokande
     (HK) project, the next generation neutrino oscillation experiment in
     Japan.  Hyper-Kamaiokande is being designed to make the world leading
     measurements of leptonic CP violation.  The Canadian Hyper-K group has
     received funding to design, build and install half the photosensors
     for IWCD by 2026.
    
     The goal of this position is to help with the testing of the high
     speed electronics for IWCD multi-PMT photosensor (mPMT). The mPMT is
     composed of 3" photo-multiplier tubes placed inside a transparent
     pressure vessel along with their readout electronics.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     We have fabricated prototype electronics cards for the mPMT readout.
     The student will assist with developing the software for reading out
     the electronics cards and will lead the data analysis.  In particular,
     the student will:
     * Use and improve the software for acquiring data from the electronics
     mainboard.
     * Analyze the data from the electronics card and characterize the
     electronics and the PMTs.
     * Develop automated acquisition scripts and analysis software for
     calibration and quality control.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     * Readout of modern, high speed custom electronics.
     * Data acquisition software and web control.
     * Operation and characteristic of PMTs.
     * Analysis of PMT waveform to extract pulse features.
     * Techniques for large scale data processing.
 
Qualifications:
     Essential skills:
     * Experience with C++ (or closely related language).
     * Experience with scientific computing and data analysis.
     * Good communication and problem solving skills.
    
     Beneficial skills:
     * Experience with custom electronics, high speed electronics or
     development electronics like Arduinos.
     * Experience with data acquisition software.
     * Experience with PMTs.
     * Experience with Linux operating system.
     * Experience with python or javascript/html.

Shiftwork required: No
 
Period of Work: May - Aug 2021, with possible 4-month extension

Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-20
 
Student job title:
     REMOTE or MIX of ON-SITE - Photon detection solution developer
     possible)
 
Name of project:
     Light detection in liquid Xenon
 
Overview:
     The nEXO experiment is being designed to search for a very decay of a
     Xenon nuclei, whose detection would show that neutrinos are they own
     anti-particle. Efficient detection of the Xenon scintillation light is
     one of the key to the experiment success. Scintillation photons travel
     through the detector before hitting photo-detectors called silicon
     photo-multipliers (SiPM). The project is about characterizing the
     processes that the photons encounter from their production to their
     detection. The long term aim of the project is to develop accurate
     simulation of photon detection in nEXO enabling of machine learning
     reconstruction algorithms.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     The project goals will be achieved by combining data from the Light
     only Liquid Xenon (LoLX) experiment with measurements of material
     optics properties  using the VERA setup at TRIUMF. If the project is
     100% remote the focus will be primarily on the LoLX data analysis.
     LoLX is a baseball size liquid Xenon experiment with internal
     radioactive sources generating scintillation surrounded by 96 SiPMs
     detecting the scintillation (and Cerenkov) light.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     Vacuum ultra-violet optics and detection, Light production processes
     in radiation detectors, Monte Carlo simulation technique, data
     analysis using C++ tools.
 
Qualifications:
     Experience programming in C++ and the Linux operating system. Some
     experience in laboratory work.
 
Shiftwork required: No

Job Title:
NEW
									



										Atom Trap for Beta Decay Research Assistant
Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-1
 
Student job title:
     ON-SITE: Atom trap for beta decay Research Assistant
 
Name of project:
     Nuclear beta decay: particle physics with atom traps
 
Overview:
     We have completed the most accurate beta decay asymmetry ever
     measured, by measuring the difference in number of betas emitted with
     and against the nuclear spin direction. This is the observable first
     used by Wu et al. in 1957 to discover that parity symmetry is violated
     by the weak interaction.  We have improved their experiment by an
     order of magnitude using an atom trap, using the absorption of
     circularly polarized light to both spin-polarize the atoms and measure
     the achieved polarization.
      We have also made first tests of time-reversal breaking in radiative
     beta decay, adding gamma-ray detection.
      We are upgrading these experiments to do better, and want to improve
     both the degree of spin polarization, and how well we measure it. To
     prepare to do this with radioactive atoms which require rare beamtime
     from the main cyclotron, we must do several technical tasks with
     readily available stable atoms, including improving the sensitivity of
     the atomic probes.  Depending on student interest and experience, this
     term may include gamma-ray detector development, in addition to the
     optical probes.
    
     Pandemic protocols: This research would be about 2 days/week at
     TRIUMF, with all planning, design, and analysis done from home. The
     position may not allow any additional travel from outside BC. The
     on-site research will follow the ALARA (exposure As Low as Reasonably
     Achievable) principle borrowed from radiation safety.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     1 to 2 of the following tasks, depending on student experience and
     interest: Couple an ultraviolet laser into an optical fiber to
     photoionize and probe atoms.  Improve understanding of direct optical
     probes of the atomic polarization. Help with development of gamma-ray
     scintillation detector with SiPM readout.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     UV laser alignment and triggering, control programming, gamma-ray
     detection.
 
Qualifications:
     Physics or Engineering Physics student preferred. Optics course and/or
     lab would be an asset. Electronics lab with equivalent of Horowitz and
     Hill would be an asset. Some quantum mechanics would be helpful to
     understand the atom trapping. C++ programming would be an asset.
 
Shiftwork required: No
 
Period of Work: May 2021-August 2021, with possible 4-month extension

Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-21
 
Student job title:
     REMOTE - Undergraduate Research Assistant
 
Name of project:
     Particle Reconstruction and Identification via Deep Learning with the
     ATLAS Detector
 
Overview:
     Proton-proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider in Geneva,
     Switzerland produce hundreds of particles that are recorded by the
     ATLAS detector. The ATLAS detector uses a variety of detector
     technologies to measure and identify these particles, and currently
     hand-designed algorithms are used to combine inputs from each
     detector. TRIUMF, in collaboration with other laboratories, is
     currently leading a new effort to instead use deep learning techniques
     to combine these measurements and use the best information possible to
     improve the efficiency of identification and the resolution of energy
     measurements. This project will focus on developing techniques using
     convolutional and graph neural networks to devise these new
     reconstruction strategies and quantify the performance improvements of
     these techniques. These studies can lead to a substantial improvement
     in ATLAS's ability to interpret its data and identify signatures of
     physics beyond the Standard Model.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     The selected student will analyze simulated data and potentially
     recorded collisions produced by the ATLAS Collaboration. The student
     will develop workflows to analyze the data, and to combine disparate
     detector technologies in single datasets. The student will develop
     deep learning models to combine information from different detectors,
     and will quantify the efficiency of reconstruction and the accuracy of
     energy regression. The student will regularly report in ATLAS-TRIUMF
     group meetings, and in broader ATLAS meetings.
     This project is expected to be fully remote.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     Students will learn to utilize modern data-science analysis workflows
     such as Pandas and TensorFlow in Python, as well as frameworks
     utilizing ROOT in C++. They will learn the detailed properties of
     particle detectors such as trackers and calorimeters, and the relative
     qualities of these detectors in the ATLAS experiment. They will learn
     how to quantify the performance of a detector in the complicated
     environment of hadron colliders. Students will learn to present their
     work to collaborators and broader audiences.
 
Qualifications:
     Students should have familiarity with particle physics at the
     undergraduate level. Experience with programming, especially in C++
     and Python, is an advantage. Experience with particle detectors (in
     class, or previous research experience, etc.) is an advantage.
     Familiarity with modern analysis packages (Pandas, etc.) and machine
     learning is a plus. Third year students and above are preferred, but
     exceptional students at younger years will be considered.
 
Shiftwork required: No
 
Period of Work: May - Aug 2021

Job Title:
NEW
									



										Cyclotron Stray Field Compensation System
Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-26
 
Student job title:
     ON-SITE - Cyclotron stray field compensation system student
 
Name of project:
     Field compensation study for the TRIUMF cyclotron horizontal injection
     section
 
Overview:
     The TRIUMF 500 MeV cyclotron is the workhorse of the laboratory
     producing a variety of beams for science and applications. The
     cyclotron relies on the electrostatic injection beam line to maintain
     its availability above 90%. The injection line can be divided into two
     main sections: the horizontal and the vertical. The vertical section
     has been replaced a few years ago, but the horizontal is still the
     original one in service now for almost 50 years. In order to maintain
     reliability and reduce maintenance, the horizontal section needs to be
     replaced; this is an approved project (P481) that has been initiated
     and must be completed in this 2020-25 five-year cycle. One aspect to
     address in the design of the new horizontal injection section is the
     compensation of the cyclotron stray magnetic field (that is presently
     accomplished in a passive mode with soft steel enclosures and
     permanent magnets); the first step requires to map the stray magnetic
     field at the horizontal section level in order to properly design the
     new compensation system.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     Working with the P481 project team to characterize the stray magnetic
     field along the horizontal injection beamline and study potential
     compensation systems (passive vs active); duties include:
     - Measuring the stray magnetic field from Ion source terminal two (I2)
     to the first horizontal 90-deg. bend section.
     - Measuring the stray magnetic field from the second horizontal
     90-deg. bend section to the 90-deg. vertical bend section of the
     injection line.
     - Modelling compensation schemes in OPERA: active (Helmholtz-type
     coils) and passive (soft steel shielding)
     - Recording the magnetic field survey and draft a report.
     - Additional/optional scope: prototyping and characterization of
     compensation systems.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     - Acquire knowledge in magnetic fields, and in particular gain
     experience in magnetic field measurements
     - Design of a magnetic field compensation system (shielding)
     - Prototyping and characterization of a magnetic field compensation
     system 
     - Simulations and programming skills: OPERA, Python, MATLAB.         

Qualifications:
     Physics or Engineering Physics - 2nd year or higher
 
Shiftwork required: No
 
Period of Work: May - Aug 2021, with possible 4-month extension

Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-27
 
Student job title:
     ON-SITE - Mechanical and Electrical Testing Student
 
Name of project:
     Target and Ion Source Acceptance Stand Mechanical and Electrical
     Testing
 
Overview:
     TRIUMF is Canada's national laboratory for particle and nuclear
     physics and accelerator-based science. Our 500 MeV cyclotron provides
     the proton driver beams for the majority of TRIUMF's current on-site
     research programs, which include molecular and materials science and
     nuclear medicine, physics and astrophysics. There are two ISOL
     (Isotope Separator On-Line) facilities on-site. The ISAC facility has
     been producing and accelerating radioactive ion beams with the highest
     power driver beam in the world since 1999. The Advanced Rare IsotopE
     Laboratory (ARIEL) is currently under development and will expand
     TRIUMF's (and Canada's) capabilities to produce and study radioactive
     isotopes for cutting edge research. There will be two new driver
     beam?target interaction stations for the production of exotic isotopes
     at ARIEL, the first accepting a 100 kW, 35 MeV electron driver beam
     and the second accepting a 50 kW, 500 MeV proton driver beam. The
     ARIEL test stands are a critical step in the design process of the
     ARIEL target stations, since our group relies on off-line development
     to validate designs and troubleshoot problems before they are
     committed to an on-line installation. This development is done
     primarily on test stands which are modular and undergo frequent
     upgrades. The test stands also provide the opportunity for the
     development of new ideas and techniques, which translate directly into
     better operation of TRIUMF's radioactive ion beam facilities. The
     Target and Ion Source Acceptance (TISA) test stand is on the ARIEL
     Electron Target East (AETE) target station critical path and is
     scheduled to enter operation in 2021. To achieve this, all the
     required mechanical and electrical systems must be installed and
     validated. These systems will include high voltage, signal processing,
     high pressure actuation, vacuum, electrical and mechanical tasks.
     Documentation of all tests performed will also be required.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     The student will provide assistance during electrical testing of the
     TISA front end. This includes HV testing and electrical service
     delivery. Support for this will include setup, wiring, following a
     test plan, general engineering simulation/calculation support and
     documentation.
     The student will also provide assistance during mechanical testing of
     the TISA front end. This may include continuing previous work to
     facilitate alignment calculations of the position of the front end,
     and continuing work to validate the high pressure piston coupling
     system.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     The student will learn a variety of skills related to high voltage,
     vacuum, electrical and high pressure systems. They will also develop
     skills related to simulation, calculation, engineering design and
     presentation. They will work with a wide range of professionals which
     will help them develop a complete understanding of the engineering
     lifecycle.
 
Qualifications:
     - Mech.Eng. student
     - Must be interested in conducting hands-on assembly and experimental
     work, and have some familiarity with working in a laboratory.
     - Must have motivation to learn across a wide variety of subjects,
     some outside the candidate's direct subject area
     - Knowledge of mechanical design principles would be an asset        
                                                                          
Shiftwork required: No

Student job title:
     ON-SITE but could be REMOTE - Superconducting RF (SRF) Cavity Design Student
 
Name of project:
     Balloon Variant of Multi-spoke Cavity Design
 
Overview:
     Spoke resonator is a high performance SRF cavity for low-medium
     velocity section in proton or ion accelerators. TRIUMF has
     successfully conceptualized, designed and prototyped a new variant of
     the single spoke resonator called the balloon cavity. It demonstrated
     the balloon cavity mitigated the significant multipacting issue in
     conventional spoke resonators. TRIUMF would like to maintain
     leadership in this area by extending the design to multi-spoke
     cavities.
Job Responsibilities:

     The student will work under close supervision of the SRF physicist and
     technical staff with input from SRF designer to support the design of
     a multi-spoke balloon cavity.

     FEA analysis. This will be an invaluable experience for a student of
     Mechanical Engineering or Engineering Physics.

Job Title:
NEW
									



										Life Sciences Division Chemistry Research Assistant
Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-13
 
Student job title:
[ONSITE]     Life Sciences Division Chemistry Research Assistant
 
Name of project:
     Synthesis and evaluation of chelates for targeted radionuclide therapy
 
Overview:
     TRIUMF Life Sciences Division maintains a strong medical isotope and
     radiopharmaceutical production and development capability enabled by
     the unique infrastructures including four cyclotrons and deep
     expertise. The program supports local and international users
     conducting high-impact research including the production of novel
     clinically relevant isotopes, radiopharmaceutical development for
     cancer diagnosis and treatment, imaging of neurodegeneration diseases,
     and cutting-edge new technologies in nuclear medicine.  One of our
     major research efforts is to develop and test novel chelates to
     harness the powerful radionuclides for cancer diagnosis and treatment,
     i.e. targeted radionuclide therapy. The chelates under development in
     our labs have been successfully used to label therapeutical isotopes
     such as Ac-225, Lu-177, and others. When conjugated with a targeting
     vector, the radiopharmaceuticals demonstrated tumor-specific
     accumulation in several preclinical studies.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     The successful candidate will join the effort of developing the next
     generation radiopharmaceuticals for targeted radionuclide therapy.
     She/He will take part in the organic synthesis, characterization, and
     radiolabelling and also participate in the in vitro and in vivo
     evaluation.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     Hands-on knowledge and experience with organic synthesis, analysis,
     radiochemistry, and chemical biology will be learned.  Basic knowledge
     in radiopharmaceutical sciences and radiotracer development will be
     acquired.  Documentation and presentation skills will be practiced.
 
Qualifications:
     The successful candidate will be a chemistry student with lab
     experience. Experience with organic synthesis and characterization
     (NMR, MS) is required. Experience with other analytical methods (HPLC,
     UV) and communication skills will be considered an asset.
 
Shiftwork required: No
 
Period of Work: May - Aug 2021, with possible 4-month extension

Job Summary:
TRIUMF
Canada's National Laboratory for Particle and Nuclear Physics STUDENT JOB PROGRAM Summer 2021 job posting Job number TR21-2-22
 
Student job title:
     REMOTE - Undergraduate Research Assistant
 
Name of project:
 Trigger optimization for selection of Higgs Boson pair events with the ATLAS Detector.
 
Overview:
     After the discovery of the Higgs boson by the ATLAS and CMS
     collaborations in 2012, the observation of a simultaneous two Higgs
     production (di-Higgs) at the LHC is now gaining a constantly growing
     attention in High Energy Physics research due to its potential to
     unveil important questions about cosmology and physics Beyond the
     Standard Model (BSM). However, the future increase in the number of
     simultaneous proton-proton collisions at the LHC will make the
     selection of di-Higgs signals complicated due to the difficulty of the
     ATLAS Trigger and Data Acquisition system (TDAQ) to cope with such a
     high event rate. An update of the ATLAS multi-jet trigger strategy
     will then be essential to maintain the selection of double-Higgs
     events decaying to four b-jets (HH-->4b) high and enhance the
     sensitivity of the ATLAS detector to new physics in this signature.
     This project will explore the potential of novel calorimeter-based
     techniques for the selection of Higgs candidates in multi-jet
     high-pileup events, targeting improvements in the selection of HH-->4b
     signals and possibly resulting in an important update of the next
     ATLAS trigger strategy for this signature.
Job Responsibilities:
Duties:
     The selected student will analyze simulated data and potentially
     recorded collisions produced by the ATLAS Collaboration. The student
     will develop workflows to analyze the data, and devise selection
     strategies to select signal and remove background events. The student
     will assess the selection efficiency of these strategies, and their
     suitability for integration into the ATLAS trigger system. The student
     will regularly report in ATLAS-TRIUMF group meetings, and in broader
     ATLAS meetings.
     This position is expected to be fully remote.
Required Skills:
Skills learned during this work experience:
     Students will learn to utilize simulated data from the ATLAS detector
     using Python and C++ using ROOT and other frameworks. They will learn
     the detailed properties of particle detectors such as trackers and
     calorimeters and how they are utilized in trigger decisions made by
     the detector. Students will learn to present their work to
     collaborators and broader audiences.
 
Qualifications:
     Students should have familiarity with particle physics at the
     undergraduate level. Experience with programming, especially in C++
     and Python, is an advantage. Experience with particle detectors (in
     class, or previous research experience, etc.) is an advantage. Third
     year students and above are preferred, but exceptional students at
     younger years will be considered.
 
Shiftwork required: No
 
Period of Work: May - Aug 2021
Targeted Degrees and Disciplines:
Targeted Clusters
			

		
		
			
				- Theme - Energy Production and Distribution
				
			
				- Theme - Scientific Experimental Design and Laboratory Assistance
				
			
				ENG - Electrical and Computer Engineering
				
			
				MATH - Computer Science
				
			
				SCI - Physics

Job Summary:
Trustwave helps businesses fight cybercrime, protect data and reduce security risk. With cloud and managed security services, integrated technologies and a team of security experts, ethical hackers and researchers, Trustwave enables businesses to transform the way they manage their information security and compliance programs. Trustwave delivers automated, efficient and cost-effective threat, vulnerability and compliance management. Trustwave is a privately held company, headquartered in Chicago, with customers in 96 countries. For more information about Trustwave, visit https://www.trustwave.com .  You are also encouraged to check out our company blog at https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/trustwave-blog/ .
 
The Trustwave Waterloo engineering team is responsible for developing the Trustwave SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) line of products.  SIEM systems provide identification, analysis and recovery of enterprise network security events.  SIEMs collect event data from security devices such as firewalls, IDS, IPS, etc. and correlate this information to produce threat scenarios which can then by analyzed and acted upon.

Our Waterloo office offers a comfortable workspace, great learning environment, and an opportunity to work with some of the best in the industry! Our office is currently closed due to COVID-19 and our employees are all working from home.  We will revisit a reopening plan in January 2021.
Job Responsibilities: The successful candidate will be a member of the SIEM Engineering team and be assigned various hands-on tasks from all areas of the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC).  With the software development team, work will include developing, debugging, unit testing and documentation for the current SIEM project(s). With the QA team, work may involve functionality verification, tooling and automated test script development and test planning. Developing automated test for our Machine Learning based analytical engine is one such project area that recent co-op students have worked on.  Additional duties may be assigned as they present themselves and specific allotment of tasks will depend on current projects and the specific aptitudes and interests of the successful candidate.
Required Skills:
Essential Skills:

Working towards a Degree in Computer Science, Engineering, Math
Software Development experience in an Object-Oriented Environment
1 or more years Java development experience 
Basic Linux and IT skills
An understanding of client-server and multi-threaded programming
An understanding of Software Quality Assurance and the SDLC model
Familiarity with security products such as firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and anti-virus software
Solid team player with good communication abilities
Able to work and thrive in a fast-paced environment
Java, Python, Swing, JSP, MySQL, and/or J2EE experience considered an asset


Nice to Have Skills:

Experience with leading open source frameworks such as Spring, Hibernate, JUnit, Maven, etc.
Relational DBMS skills using MySQL, MariaDB or PostgresSQL products.
Familiarity with Big Data and Stream processing technologies such as Elastic Search, Storm, Kafka.
Familiarity with agile/iterative development methodologies
Understanding of Machine Learning concepts (e.g., TensorFlow).
Prior experience with RESTful API's
Cloud Computing experience (AWS, Azure, GCP, etc)

Job Summary:
We are Tuq. If you need an App built that you care about then you've come to the right place. We don't take on projects that we aren't passionate about and we're passionate about every project we take on! That means we pass on a lot of what other companies call "lucrative" work, and that commitment to quality and dedication to the products we create is the reason that we're willing to put in our time, energy, and lifesblood into everything we build. The name's not just a catchy one-syllable word, it's an affirmation of who we are and what we stand for: Trustworthy Uncompromising Quality!

Do you want to work on REAL projects for REAL clients and make valuable contributions that make a REAL difference?
Job Responsibilities:
Come work for Tuq! Here are some of the things you can look forward to:
- Work with companies BIG and small, and work with multiple teams, with different styles.
- Company dinners.
- No Mornings!
- Difficult, real-world challenges to tackle.
- Work on a variety of projects - from Text and Video Chat, to GPS, Gaming, and Internet of Things-connected devices.

Still not convinced? Just listen to these glowing testimonials:

"It's a fast-paced, self-driven workplace where you get the opportunity to work alongside some of the best developers in the industry." - Ernst Rullmann

"I got to work on a variety of real projects with a range of technologies and languages that I never would have expected. One co-op term at Tuq will teach you more than you could have thought possible in 4 months." - Daniel Mackenzie

"It's great, and Mike has a sword!" - Areal C. Oop
Required Skills:
What we're looking for:
Someone who's smart, self-motivated, independent, and always looking to learn. Must be willing and able to pick up new languages and technology, and not be afraid to fail early and often. No specific previous experience necessary, but a familiarity with basic programming principles is a must. Being able to work from home is also a plus!

Want to get a head-start? Answer one of the following questions and submit the answer with your resume.

QUESTIONS:

1. Code TicTacToe with a usable interface in a language of your choice.
2. Create an database diagram (along with all required joins and model details) for a simple messaging app capable of sending messages, attaching files (images and text), and having group chats.
3. You've been hired to build an image-sharing app where people can recommend products to each other. Describe and defend the technology you would use, including a front-end app and a back-end server system.

Job Summary:
TwoBite Digital Inc. is a Toronto-based digital marketing agency that specializes in paid advertising/media buying, specifically Google Ads and Facebook Ads. We're looking for a co-op who can help with creating and updating client-facing reports and presentations as well as contribute valuable digital marketing ideas to help our clients grow. We are hoping to introduce a co-op to our team to help support our existing SEM team and help our business with ongoing tasks as well as providing your unique insight and perspective to help us ensure that we are exceeding our clients' expectations. 

TwoBite operates remotely and we will stay remote until it is completely safe to return back to in-person work. This means, for the entire duration of the spring co-op term, our team will be working from home. There may be opportunities to come into the office if the pandemic ends earlier than expected, but this will still be completely optional.

The absolute most important thing we are looking for in a candidate is attention-to-detail.  The work you produce will be client-facing so it is crucial that your work is thorough and meticulous. Aside from that, we are a small company where there are very few barriers between ideas and execution. The work you do will have a meaningful impact, not only on our business but on several clients' businesses. Because of our small size, we value honesty, transparency, and communication between members of our team.
Job Responsibilities:
Reporting on results and providing clients with valuable insights & recommendations
Writing ad copy for Google & Facebook Ads
Managing campaign spends to pace with target budgets
Keyword Research
Required Skills:
Proficiency working with Microsoft Excel/Google Sheets
Strong attention to detail
High level of comfort working with data
Copywriting skills would also be a bonus (feel free to show off your copywriting skills in a cover letter if you'd like)
Experience with Google Ads editor
Teamwork and collaboration

Job Responsibilities:
On being a Game Intelligence Intern at Ubisoft Toronto
 
The Game Intelligence Intern will work directly will be part of our data science team, working directly with senior analysts in transforming player data into insights. You will work with production teams to understand their telemetry/tracking needs, collect data (both pre and post-launch) to answer those needs, and transform that data into actionable findings that inform critical decisions and enhance the player experience.
 
Join the inter-disciplinary Ubisoft Toronto User Research Lab as Game Intelligence Intern and directly support AAA game production by being the point of contact for all things DATA.

Type: Full time, paid internship
Length of internship: 8 months
Location: Remote

The daily life of a Game Intelligence Intern (GIA) at Ubisoft Toronto

Work with production teams to determine their telemetry needs and translate these into actionable and trackable elements
Analyze, synthesize and interpret player data to identify trends, develop insights, and inform decisions
Provide teams with impactful and compelling visuals with strong storytelling
Develop and implement KPI dashboards to provide strategic and operational support for production teams
Required Skills:
What it takes to make it

BSc or BA in quant fields (Business, Economics, Math, Stats, CS) in progress
Confident in analyzing large, complex, multi-dimensional data sets with a variety of tools
SQL and Python and excited to learn new programming languages where needed
Experience in creating compelling dashboards in Tableau/PowerBI or other visualization tools
Detail-oriented with ability to problem-solve with creativity
Excellent communication skills - comfortable in explaining complex ideas in a clear manner
Passionate about data and while enjoying fast-paced environments

Job Summary:
uForis VR Inc is looking for a detail-oriented, enthusiastic, and ambitious individual to join our team in Waterloo, ON. We are a virtual reality and visualization company that believes in VR and 3D visualization as a platform for elevating the way we experience both real and artificial worlds. We specialize in photorealistic 3D architectural visualization: renderings that bring future buildings to life. They embody the owners' vision, are representative of its future inhabitants and built to specifications. We are distinguished by the quality of our work, process, and customer service. We are a flexible workplace and working from home is common among employees.

Note: If social distancing restrictions are still in place, all interviews will be conducted via video conferencing. The successful candidate will start work from home and we will provide all onboarding over video conferencing.

JOB SUMMARY: Your job will be to ensure the quality of all 3D renderings we deliver to clients. A keen attention to detail is needed to maintain the best quality of work and customer service. You must be organized, able to juggle multiple projects effectively, be willing to take the initiative on projects, and complete any necessary research so that you are prepared to shepherd the process end-to-end. Computer skills are an important requirement for this position, as you may be required to learn to use multiple programs and online platforms. Preference will be given to candidates who have prior experience in architecture, construction, interior design, or 3D visualization. This position is a 4-month co-op position.
Job Responsibilities:
RESPONSIBILITIES:
- Process and organize project materials from architecture firms, interior design firms, and marketing agencies Organize architectural visualization deliverables from 3D artists and review them for basic accuracy (referencing specifications provided by client).
- Attend internal project sync meetings and document applicable feedback on deliverables/meeting notes.
- Coordinate with 3D artists and internal project managers to ensure that deliverables are on track and meet our quality standards
Required Skills:
REQUIRED SKILLS:
- Detail-oriented. Quality-of-work is of the utmost importance and requires a keen eye for small details.
- Service-oriented. Must take ownership and respond to requests efficiently and effectively.
- Exceptional organization and communication skills. Must be confident and comfortable communicating with potential and current clients.
- Thrives in a fast-paced environment. Able to shift priorities, manage time effectively, and handle multiple projects at once.
- Proficient in all Microsoft Office programs.
- Excellent computer skills. Must be able to pick up new computer media programs quickly.

BONUS QUALIFIATIONS:
- Experience or interest in a career in project management or operations
- Experience interpreting architectural drawings an asset
- Experience with the architectural visualization process
- Experience with BIM tools, 3D modeling software, Adobe Creative Suite, Photoshop, and image editing
- Experience with interior design
- Experience with photography
- Experience/background in Marketing

We build fun social and mobile games that make people stare, smile, jump, and feel awesome inside. We have a quirky nerdy culture that fosters creativity, collaboration, quality ideas, and a data driven mindset. We believe in moving quickly and improving constantly and that mantra is reflected in the weekly updates we make to our games and internal technologies. Division: Institut national de la recherche scientifique
Job Summary:
Three summer stage positions (4 months or longer) are available in the Nonlinear Photonics Group at Institut National de la Recherche Scientifique (INRS) in Montreal, in the Énergie Matériaux Télécommunications (EMT) center.
 
INRS-EMT is an expanding, graduate degree-granting research institute located in the beautiful, dynamic and multicultural city of Montreal (in particular, Montreal was recently elected as the top city in the world in terms of quality of life, according to several independent pools).
 
INRS-EMT is an expanding, graduate degree-granting research institute located in the beautiful, dynamic and multicultural city of Montreal (ranked as one of the best cities in the world for students). INRS, the research-oriented branch of Université du Québec, is renowned as a top Canadian research university in terms of publication and research intensity ($108.4 per graduate student (rank 1 in Canada) and $482.5 per faculty (rank 1 in Canada) - RE$EARCH Infosource 2020). Our center (INRS-EMT) is devoted to the development of cutting-edge research programs in a variety of technological areas, including photonics, nanotechnologies, and telecommunications. Following a strong development of our facilities, we are now equipped with state-of-the-art laboratories and instruments (worth over $100 million) for device fabrication and characterization. For more information on our Center, please visit: http://www.emt.inrs.ca.

Our group is currently investigating innovative approaches in photonics based on various free space and integrated technologies. Our focus is in the following applications: (i) design and realization of on-chip devices for all-optical signal processing; (ii) study of fundamental light-matter interaction properties in optical waveguides; (iii) investigation of novel platforms for optoelectronics and quantum optics applications, i.e. quantum communications/computing (iv) realization of extreme terahertz infrastructure (sources, detectors, waveguides) for THz imaging and nonlinear THz optics. Our work (reported on in journals such as Physical Review Letters, Science, the Nature series, - Nature, Nature Photonics, Nature Physics, Nature Communication, etc. - and recognized with several prestigious awards) involves both theory and experimental work as well as several industrial links. For more information on our group, please visit: www.nonlinearphotonics.com.

If you are a motivated student and looking to work as part of our collaborative research group in any of the research fields listed above, please apply with a cover letter, CV, and transcripts through the WaterlooWorks Portal.
Job Responsibilities:
Requirements for these positions are relevant research and academic experiences (ideally in physics, optics, electrical engineering, or related disciplines), excellent undergraduate academic performance, and, most importantly, a keen sense of curiosity and strong work-ethic. Senior undergraduate students are especially encouraged to apply. Please note that you need to be a Permanent Resident or a Citizen of Canada to apply.

INRS is a French speaking institution (however, a previous knowledge of French is not required at the moment of the application). An independent and enthusiastic scientific attitude are the main requirements for these positions. Undergraduate students in their final year of study are especially encouraged to apply.

Specific projects will be determined and assigned to match the candidate's experience and interest as best possible.
Required Skills:
- self-motivated and driven
- an independent and enthusiastic scientific attitude
- good communication skills in writing research reports
- experience in optics/photonics (either experimental or theoretical)
Targeted Degrees and Disciplines:
Targeted Clusters
			

		
		
			
				- Theme - Scientific Experimental Design and Laboratory Assistance
				
			
				ENG - Electrical and Computer Engineering
				
			
				SCI - Physics

Job Summary:
eHealth Innovation is a group of biomedical engineers, computer scientists and hardware designers dedicated to developing technology that connect patients with healthcare providers and improve their lives. As a part of University Health Network, we are a part of one of the largest medical research centres in North America. We have good results. For example, our applications have been shown to significantly improve heart failure outcomes in patients with Congestive Heart Failure. In another we've demonstrated a 10 point drop in blood pressure for hypertensive patients. We also develop products in the areas of diabetes, asthma, chronic pain, juvenile arthritis, and prostate cancer.

Our team is smart, ambitious and passionate, and our work is driven by the desire to improve patients lives. Being in a research environment, we are able to concentrate on this goal without being distracted by short term profit motives, or keeping investors happy. Every member of our tightly knit development team has full input into every stage of project architecture, design and implementation. We own our projects and build apps that have real, meaningful and measurable impact on sick people's lives.

We are looking for a software development QA tester to join the team, with a passion and thoroughness for the work. The QA tester will work with our software development teams and perform manual and automated testing to check for product quality. You will be responsible for reporting any bugs and helping the team troubleshoot and debug any issues to ensure that our products meet requirements and work as expected.
Job Responsibilities:
Key job responsibilities include:
- Implementing and executing test plans.
- Tracking quality assurance metrics and ensuring the products run as they should
- Fully appreciating and understanding the context of use (persons who live with complex chronic conditions or clinicians during a packed clinic day) and anticipate issues in flows.
- Being familiar with the product design and its objectives.
- Generating reports and logging bugs in detail
- Reporting any problems or issues with the performance of the product to the Project Manager.
- Following the QMS system in place for medical devices
Required Skills:
The ideal candidate for this position would:
- Have knowledge in software/technology related field
- Have strong familiarity with web and mobile device technologies, browsers and operating systems
- Have strong attention to detail and documentation practice
- Be goal-oriented and focused
- Possess good judgment and decision-making skills.
- Think outside the box and come up with use cases that may not be as obvious
- Have ability to communicate to individuals with technical and non-technical knowledge
- Experience working in healthcare system is an asset, but not required
Targeted Degrees and Disciplines:
Targeted Clusters
			

		
		
			
				- Theme - Computing: Quality Assurance 
				
			
				- Theme - Computing: Software
				
			
				ENG - Electrical and Computer Engineering
				
			
				ENG - Software Engineering
				
			
				ENG - Systems Design and Biomedical Engineering

Job Summary: The DATA team is a research lab located within the University Health Network, the largest health research organization in North America. The DATA team aim to enable better and faster medicine through use of smarter computer tools. We create cutting-edge web and mobile applications, programs and databases for large-scale data collection and analytics. Our work focuses on the capture of data from clinical encounters, using both advanced User Interfaces and mining of unstructured data ( using machine learning), the analysis of omics data (genome, transcriptome, epigenome), and the development of clinician and patient portals to ease the discovery and analysis of large-scale data.
Job Responsibilities:
We are seeking a highly motivated trainee to work on the cutting edge of software development including areas of web development, scripting, statistics, data science and more.

The successful candidate will get the opportunity to work closely with researchers and scientists on a number of fast evolving exciting projects pushing any number of initiatives to the wider UHN audience. The candidate will assist in developing and customizing software, build user interfaces to suit customers needs, solve complete data analyses problems at various levels of complexity. Strong computer science skills and the ability to quickly adapt to new challenges is desired.
Required Skills:
Many of the roles main responsibilities will involve web development and database management using languages such as JavaScript (React, Express.js, GraphQL, and Node.js), MySQL and MongoDB. Applicants with strong skills listed above are encouraged to apply, especially those from the following programs and majors:

ENG - Systems Design / Biomedical
ENG - Electrical and Computer
ENG - Software
MATH - Computer Science
MATH ? Bioinformatics
MATH - Applied Mathematics

				- Theme - Information Science and Data Management 
				
			
				ENG - Electrical and Computer Engineering
				
			
				ENG - Software Engineering
				
			
				MATH - Applied Mathematics
				
			
				MATH - Computer Science

Job Summary:
WHO WE ARE:
The Familial Cancer Clinic at Princess Margaret Cancer Centre provides genetic counselling and risk assessment services to families who have an increased risk of cancer due to hereditary factors.
Visit our website: https://www.uhn.ca/PrincessMargaret

THE OPPORTUNITY:
We are seeking a highly motivated Genetic Counselling Assistant to work with our team of genetic counsellors, administrative assistants, and geneticist.  The successful candidate will interact with patients, learn the day-to-day duties of a cancer genetic counsellor and assist in administrative and technical duties.
Specifically, the genetic counselling assistant will aid clinic staff by creating and updating family pedigrees, preparing patient files, running risk assessment software, liasing with other clinics and laboratories, coordinating the work of clinic volunteers, and assisting with other projects.
Learning opportunities include the ability to attend weekly educational lectures and meetings addressing topics such as genetics, genetic counselling and cancer genetics, as well as the opportunity to observe genetics consultations.
The genetic counselling assistant may also have the opportunity to participate in patient recruitment, data analysis or manuscript preparation for ongoing research studies.
Job Responsibilities:
YOUR ROLE:
1. Elicit, update and create patient pedigrees for genetic counsellors.
2. Prepare patient charts, collect relevant medical records for accurate assessment of a patient's family members, schedule appointments and perform essential administrative tasks.
3. Learn how to use risk model software systems to accurately generate risk profiles for patients.
4. Observe genetic counselling sessions and genetics consultations for hereditary cancer syndromes.
5. Liase with other clinics and laboratories to coordinate patient care.
Required Skills:
WHAT YOU BRING:
1. Excellent communication skills and confidence to communicate with patients.
2. Excellent time management and prioritization skills with the ability to manage and follow-up on multiple tasks.
3. Detail-oriented with excellent organizational skills.
4. Interest in pursuing a career in human genetics.
5. Completed or currently taking a course in genetics with a minimum grade of 75% (i.e. BIOL 239).

Job Title: Web Interface for Large Pharmacogenomics Database
Job Summary: Description: Pharmacogenomics, combining drug screening and molecular profiling, holds great promises to develop new genomics predictors of therapy response in model systems, with the hope to translate them into clinic to improve cancer management. However, pharmacogenomic data are complex to mine and datasets are scattered and heterogeneous. We developed PharmacoGx (http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2015/12/09/bioinformatics.btv723.abstract) as a platform to analyze large-scale pharmacogenomic datasets. To easily explore these complex data, we are currently developing PharmacoDb, a web-application based on PharmacoGx: http://pharmacodb.pmgenomics.ca/.
Job Responsibilities: Implementation of a web-application
Required Skills: We are therefore looking for an intern willing to expand and improve the current interface; strong programming skills are required, web design experience preferred but not mandatory.

Job Summary:
The Haibe-Kains Lab
Our research focuses on the development of novel computational approaches to best characterize carcinogenesis, drugs, mechanisms of action and their therapeutic potential, from high-throughput genomic data. We have strong expertise in machine learning applied to biomedical problems, including the development of robust prognostic and predictive biomarkers in cancer. Our large network of national and international collaborators, including clinicians, molecular biologists, engineers, statisticians and bioinformaticians, uniquely positions us to perform cutting-edge translational research to bring discoveries from bench to bedside.
 
See our lab website for further information: http://www.pmgenomics.ca/bhklab/
 
Lab director: Dr. Benjamin Haibe-Kains, has over 10 years of experience in computational analysis of genomic data, including genomic and transcriptomic data. He is the (co-)author of more than 95 peer-reviewed articles in top bioinformatics and clinical journals. For an exhaustive list of publications, go to Dr. Haibe-Kains' Google Scholar Profile.
Job Responsibilities:
Research Assistant working under Dr. Haibe-Kains.

You Will Be Responsible For:

Image segmentation
Applying machine learning computer vision models to tasks in medical imaging
Literature review (reading research papers)
Meeting with my supervisor regularly to provide updates
Required Skills:
What You Bring:

Analytical abilities
Critical Thinking and problem solving skills
Ability to conduct research journal search
Detailed-oriented
Understanding of Coding (MySQL, C, JavaScript, GIT, Aigile)
Excellent communication and teamwork
Time management

 
How You Will Be Supervised:

We will have active weekly meetings over zoom to keep track of the progress of his project.

The job training includes identification of diseasess, computer software packages, the safe operation of field and lab equipment. Skills in data analysis, report writing and project management will be developed.

Job Summary:
Overview:
From as early as the 1960s, the Department of Medical Biophysics has run a Summer Student program for undergraduate students interested in interdisciplinary biological, medical and cancer research. This program provides an opportunity for undergraduate students to gain experience in biomedical research and to learn about the graduate program offered by the department. Students who are chosen to participate in the program are highly motivated to return to Medical Biophysics for graduate studies and serve as ambassadors, promoting the Medical Biophysics graduate program to their peers.

Learn more at https://medbio.utoronto.ca/FAQ-summer-student-program

Medical Biophysics:
Medical Biophysics is an interdisciplinary medical research program. The program focuses on both basic and applied cancer research, offering opportunities for investigation in a wide variety of projects. This often cuts across the conventional boundaries of biology, medicine, chemistry, physics, engineering, and computer science. Learn about Medical Biophysics.

Research Areas:
We offer leading-edge biomedical research opportunities in

Biomedical Imaging
Cancer Diagnosis & Therapy
Cancer Mechanisms & Models
Cardiovascular Sciences
Data Science & Computational Biology
Image-Guided Therapy & Device Development
Neuroscience
Stem Cells & Regenerative Medicine
Structural Biology

Length of the Program:
The program runs for a minimum of 12 weeks, but may continue for the entire summer. The official start date of our program is typically in early May.

Work Schedule:
Typically, you would work 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m., Monday to Friday. This is flexible, however, you would need to discuss a different work schedule with your supervisor. Please note, that if you do not work all the working days of the month, you will not be paid the full salary amount.
Job Responsibilities:
Your Role:
Throughout the summer, selected students are involved in a research project and are expected to attend weekly lunchtime seminars.

At the end of the summer, students are required to present their work in the form of a poster at the Summer Student Poster Day. All staff, postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and summer students are invited to participate in these presentations.

This public forum has traditionally been well attended, and has allowed the students to gain valuable experience in presenting their work to others, and in developing their skills in engaging in vibrant scientific interchange.
Required Skills:
Who Can Apply:
The Summer Student program is open to all university students in their first, second or third year of undergraduate study. Co-op students in their 4th (out of 5) years are also encouraged to apply.  

Successful applicants have a strong record of academic achievement and have a demonstrated interest for scientific research.

The minimum required GPA for all applicants is at least a B+ average (>76.5%) for all University courses completed to date. However, only the most talented and promising students are selected for interviews with prospective supervisors, and approximately 50 students are admitted in the program each summer.

Awards are available in specific areas of research while other students can work with their future supervisor to apply for CIHR and NSERC awards.

Division: Centre for the Advancement of Co-op Education
Job Summary:
The Work-Learn Institute (WxL, formerly WatCACE) was established to further Waterloo's leadership role in co-operative education. WxL advances co-operative education practice through conducting and disseminating research. The purpose of this position is to support research activities within WxL.
 
Examples of current research initiatives within WxL include: (1) the impact of COVID-19 on students' (remote) work term and onboarding process; (2) assessing (measuring) co-op students' lifelong learning attributes. The successful applicant would be involved in the continued success of such initiatives and may also be involved in the conceptualization and management of new research projects.
Job Responsibilities:
Key responsibilities for this position include:
1. Conducting research on a broad range of topics within the work-integrated education field.
2. Supporting the production of high-calibre research output, including peer reviewed manuscripts, conference presentations, and other knowledge products (e.g., research briefs, executive summaries, literature reviews).
3. Supporting the promotion of WxL and work-integrated education research within the Waterloo community and abroad.
Required Skills:
Qualified candidates can come from any academic discipline and can have any number of previous work terms/experiences. However, successful applicants should demonstrate:
1. An understanding of the research process applicable to the social sciences (typically gained through formal coursework regarding research and/or previous research experience).
2. Strong verbal and written communication. Preference will be given to individuals with documented success in reading, writing about, and speaking to existing research (e.g., conducting literature reviews, giving presentations about research).
3. Both convergent (i.e., focused problem solving) and divergent (e.g., creativity, "brainstorming") thinking.
4. Ability to work both independently under minimal supervision and the ability to work together within a small group environment.
 
Specific skills that are useful but not necessary would include using presentation software (e.g., PowerPoint, Prezi) and data analysis software (e.g., SPSS, NVivo).

Job Summary:
The Co-operative and Experiential Education (CEE) team is looking for an exceptional Video Content Development Associate. This role is open to any student with strong technical video development skills, as well as to students from the University of Waterloo's Global Business and Digital Arts (GBDA) Internship program.

This position is an integral part of the Communications, Engagement and Digital Experience team, which focuses on building and strengthening CEE's brand portfolio.

As the Video Content Development Associate, you'll work closely with our team of experts to provude a highly visible video series celebrating employers associated with the Co-operative Education program here at the Unviersity of Waterloo. Over the course of the internship, you'll leverage your experience and skills in filmmaking, editing and graphic design. This position will encompass all aspects of video production, including, but not limited to, pre-production planning, videography, editing, sound recording, closed captioning and graphic design. 

Our team is made up of friendly, innovative and supportive people who thrive on collaboration and fresh ideas. Join our team and help us bring exciting projects and initiatives to life!

Job Summary:
Job Summary
The successful candidate will work in a team environment within an innovative and exciting professional school at the University of Waterloo.  The School of Accounting and Finance (SAF) offers 4 distinct undergraduate programs to lead students to the professional business career they've always wanted: Accounting and Financial Management, Computing and Financial Management, Math/CPA, Biotech/CPA.
 
The Marketing and Recruitment Associate (the Associate) will use his/her marketing, event management, customer service, and communication skills to assist with the development, implementation, and management of the various student outreach, recruitment, and conversion events and initiatives. The Associate will use appropriate analytical and research skills to conduct research and provide reports to the SAF Marketing and Recruitment team to help enhance and drive strategy. The Associate will be exposed to multiple initiatives during the term and therefore, must be able to learn quickly, manage multiple tasks/projects simultaneously and act in a professional and ethical manner. The focus of the Spring term is to assist the SAF Marketing and Recruitment team with the implementation of marketing, outreach, and recruitment strategies as well as building new digital programming and initiatives. 

Due to exposure to confidential student records, AFM, Biotech/CPA and Math/CPA students are ineligible for this role (conflict of interest); therefore, any applications from students in those programs will not be considered.
Job Responsibilities:
The position involves:

Assisting with the planning, development and implementation of various student outreach/recruitment/conversion initiatives such as, but not limited to:
	
Ontario Universities' Fair
Fall Open House, March Break Open House, You @ Waterloo Day
SAF Outreach and Ambassador Program (SOAP)
DECA Provincials, DECA Entrepreneurship Conference, DECA Leadership GRIT Conference
Warm & Fuzzy letter writing campaign
Prospective student tours
High school outreach presentations


Assisting with the planning, development and implementation of the SAF's and AFM's strategic marketing strategies such as, but not limited to:
	
Digital outreach, recruitment, and conversion strategies
Web and social media strategies


Conduct research, evaluate and report findings for topic areas such as, but not limited to:
	
Competitor universities and programs
		
Recruitment activities and strategies
Prospective student websites
Program offerings and admission requirements


Focus groups


Performing administrative duties such as, but not limited to:
	
Review and provide customized answers to enquiries from afm@uwaterloo.ca
Creating and/or updating process documents
Organizing and taking inventory of all brochures, swag, event supplies, etc
Other projects that may arise under the direction of the Manager, Marketing and Recruitment.
Required Skills:
Qualifications required:

Excellent written and verbal communication skills including public speaking experience
Exceptional attention to detail
Exceptional customer service skills
Strong organizational skills
Event planning and management skills

Job Summary:
The MSAM Lab provides a unique multidisciplinary research environment for the development of next-generation additive manufacturing (AM) technologies, intelligent AM control systems, process simulation and modeling, materials development as well as characterization techniques  for different AM processes. These processes are deployed to a variety of sectors ranging from medical, sensing, energy, aerospace, automotive, tooling, remanufacturing, etc.

The selected applicant will assist with the design, development, and analysis of various AM systems and their respective processes. One aspect of this will include general design for AM work in support of MSAM's existing laser powder bed fusion, filament deposition modeling and polyjet AM systems. This can range from designing test samples to fixtures or add-ons that will be integrated with an existing machine. Another aspect of the job will include design for additive manufacturing (DFAM), which involves the consideration of AM constraints when designing parts or fixtures.

The successful application will work with a group of research engineers in the MSAM Lab, as well as external clients and researchers to print parts and develop the system.
Job Responsibilities:
Design and development of parts and subsystems of novel AM systems
Design verification and analysis of components and assemblies
Create and update mechanical engineering drawings
Develop work procedures for system assembly and maintenance
Assembly, testing, characterization of AM sub systems or samples
Operation of printing and characterization equipment may be included. Proper training will be given prior to such tasks
Required Skills:
Knowledge of materials and mechanical properties used for manufacturing
Familiar with SolidWorks (or comparable CAD package)
Experience with mechanical engineering drawings (dimensioning, GD&T, etc.)
Knowledge of basic machining methods and practices
Ability to work independently with minimal supervision
Familiarity with AM processes an asset

Job Summary:
The Emerging Radio Systems Group (EmRG) led by Dr. Slim Boumaiza employs undergraduate, graduate, and post-graduate personnel for research into advanced radio frequency (RF) communication technologies (efficiency enhancement and linearization of power amplifiers, design and fabrication of millimeter-wave integrated circuits, etc.) and associated techniques (baseband digital signal processing, semiconductor device modelling, etc.). The EmRG lab, endowed with state of the art RF test and measurement equipment, provides a leading edge environment for experiential learning to students, who typically go on to secure highly sought after positions in industry as RF specialists, hardware designers, and product/application engineers.
 
At EmRG, co-op researchers have the opportunity to work with senior research engineers and graduate students, and be involved in all stages of the engineering research and design process, from literature review, to implementation, to testing and validation. The co-op researcher will be working on contributing towards the development of a technology demonstrator for an unmanned arial vehicle (UAV) communication. This project is part of a large and diverse international consortium, HEFPA (https://hefpa.com/).
 
The ideal candidate would possess a curiosity for learning, an aptitude for critical thinking and analysis, and the initiative to investigate design challenges with limited supervision, while actively seeking guidance where appropriate.
Job Responsibilities:
Perform market study of UAVs for 5G wireless communication.
Conduct mechanical and electrical studies of the identified options and determine the most suitable UAV.
Study the software development kits of the UAV
Develop a software application for the ground control station allowing the required features. Of particular importance, develop a robust interface with the onboard FPGA.
Conduct basic communication test between the UAV and a ground station.
Required Skills:
A cumulative average of at least 80% is required.
3rd or 4th year students preferred, especially those who have taken courses in computer hardware, software development, wireless communications, etc.
Critical thinking, reading, and communication skills
Ability to take initiative and seek guidance in an openly collaborative environment
Prior experience with Linux OS, Xilinx development tool, mechanical design tools (Autocad) is an asset.

Job Title:
NEW
									



										Engineering Research Assistant - Environmental Remediation
Job Summary:
Contaminated sites are present in many rural and urban areas across Canada. While these lands may pose a threat to human or ecosystem health, they also are an impediment to urban intensification which harms local economies. If these sites are remediated, redeveloped and returned to productive use, they can generate significant economic, environmental, and social benefits. To increase remedial efficiency, it is vital to develop new technologies for specific application in addition to enhancing those which already exist.
 
This position is to support graduate students conducting novel research in the Soil and Groundwater Remediation Engineering Group. While you will be exposed to various innovative remedial technologies, your primary involvement will be supporting a project related to the use of carbon based particulates to treat petroleum hydrocarbon plumes in situ.
Job Responsibilities:
Working under the supervision of graduate students, you will assist with various research activities, including: laboratory batch and column experiments conducted in anaerobic conditions; performing chemical analyses, data entry and analysis; and other related tasks as assigned.
Work to be performed during normal business hours only.
Required Skills:
Previous laboratory experience is not a requirement. We are looking for a student who is willing to learn, ask questions, and work in an academic research environment.
 
- Excellent oral and written communication skills
- Strong interpersonal and organization skills
- High attention to details
- Proficient in Microsoft Office Suite
- Ability to multitask and work with a dynamic schedule
- Able to work independently, as well as part of a team
 
Background in contaminant hydrogeology, chemistry and/or biology is an asset.

Job Summary:
The Faculty of Environment is committed to attracting the best and the brightest students to help shape a sustainable future. To do this, the Marketing and Recruitment team creates and implements initiatives to help increase undergraduate enrollment. As the Recruitment and Marketing Associate, you'll be helping to plan and execute recruitment activities like Open Houses, overseeing our Student Ambassador Team, contributing to our social media presence, and interacting with future Environment students. We are looking for a personable, organized, and creative individual to help us work towards these goals in a fast-paced, people-first environment.

NOTE: The successful candidate must have received OSAP funding in the term immediately before the work term to be eligible for this position.

Please be mindful that in the uncertainty of COVID-19 this role's responsibilities will be more focused on digital marketing and virtual recruitment efforts instead of event planning and execution.
Job Responsibilities:
A typical day (if there is one) may look like:

Start out by checking the CRM to see if anyone has booked a tour, then meet our guests in the Visitors Centre and show them around our Environment buildings
Edit a video profiling one of our students who just completed a really cool co-op job
Respond to an email from an International student looking into admission requirements
Make recommendations on where we should target recruitment activities by analyzing prospective student data gathered from a survey you conducted
Attend a Recruitment Roundtable meeting and share ideas on what our Open House sessions will offer
Make edits to our webpages and program flyers in preparation for our next event
Brainstorm a compelling Instagram story you can create and post to engage with prospective students

Chat with one of our vendors and discuss some possible swag items to use as giveaways promoting the faculty
Required Skills:
This might be right for you if:

You're enrolled in a Faculty of Environment program.
You're an enthusiastic member of a team, able to take charge and stand in the spotlight, but also just as happy to ensure everything is running smoothly behind the scenes.
You're a natural when it comes to helping people, and make it standard to go above and beyond in your interactions with others
You're self-motivated and take initiative to start new projects without being asked
You think creatively and outside of the box, but also know how to pay attention to details and stay focused on your priorities
Your communication skills are top-notch
You are comfortable speaking to groups of people, and proud to have your writing displayed online

You might also stand out if you have:

Knowledge and passion for the Faculty of Environment's mission and values
Experience in recruitment, marketing, sales, event planning, writing, publishing, and/or public speaking
Creative skills in fine arts, digital media, photography/video making, and know how to use Adobe Creative Suite
A strong desire to learn and grow, ask questions, and bring your best each day.

Interested?

We're excited to add your energy and ideas to our team. If you feel you have only some of the qualifications we're looking for, but you're willing to work hard and learn the rest, we'd still love to see your application!

Job Summary:
Our research team focuses on:

Understanding how the brain and other parts of the central nervous system control human movement
Translating this knowledge for: early detection and prevention of decline, monitoring disease progression and treatment effectiveness, and helping individuals to maximize their recovery following a neurological injury, such as a stroke.

We interpret this information to help find ways to minimize age- and disease-related effects on movement control. We conduct research in university-based and hospital-based labs and in the community using portable cost-effective measurement tools.
The NiMBaL Lab conducts several research projects in collaboration with the Ontario Neurodegenerative Disease Research Initiative (ONDRI) (http://ondri.ca). ONDRI's objective is to improve the diagnosis and treatment of neurodegenerative diseases (NDDs). ONDRI's first large-scale study was a longitudinal cohort study capturing data from hundreds of patients across multiple assessment domains including: gait and balance, neuroimaging, neuropsychology, clinical, eye-tracking, genetics, and spectral domain optical coherence tomography. The NiMBaL lab co-leads the collection and analysis of ONDRI gait and balance data.
In 2018, the NiMBaL lab began leading a new ONDRI research initiative focused on monitoring health behaviors outside of the clinic in the home and community (ONDRI@Home). The goals of ONDRI@Home are to: translate clinical assessments into feasible, technology-based, free-living assessments completed outside of the clinic in the person's home environment. Secondly, to identify measures capable of improving diagnoses and monitoring of people with NDD. A unique challenge of the @Home project is the need to manage large volumes of data, captured from multiple sensors, measuring many behaviors over multiple days.

Job Summary
We are seeking a student who is eager to apply their expertise in data science and data engineering to improve healthcare. The student will focus on development of novel analytical approaches to maximize utility of movement related outcomes for key health indicators (e.g. activity, sleep, social engagement) derived from wearable sensor data.
Job Responsibilities:
Collaborate with the ONDRI@Home team to determine programming objectives and implement development of algorithms/programs for optimal functionality
Apply signal processing skills to biophysical signals to extract meaningful outcome measures
Generate data processing GUI for long-term data processing framework and interactive HUB for at home collection purposes.
Lead program development/implementation/debugging; ensure code is error-free, readable, efficient, and organized for subsequent users
Apply knowledge of device specifications to data collection and sensor management issues
Design and develop protocols to evaluate new wearable sensors and determine feasibility of sensors for use in research studies
Support publication efforts with writing, literature reviews, and data processing when necessary
Required Skills:
Experience in Python for data management and computational methods
Other experience in R, Java, C++, RealD 3D, Unity, Unreal Engine, Visual Studio, and the Universal Windows Platform would be an asset
Proficiency in Microsoft Office
Working knowledge of statistical methods, software, and research design
Strong independent work ethic
Strong verbal and written communication skills
Team player and successful collaborator
First aid/CPR certification is a benefit but not necessary

Job Summary:
The Cheriton School of Computer Science is looking for exceptional students currently enrolled in a Computer Science program or related areas who have a keen interest in research and in pursuing graduate studies.   
 
Students will participate in a four-month, full time, research-based co-op term (currently remote due to COVID-19) to work directly with a faculty supervisor in a particular research area (e.g., Computer Security, AI, Human-Computer Interaction, Theoretical Computer Science, etc.).   
 
Project descriptions are available on the URF website (http://grec.cs.uwaterloo.ca).  
  
A student can only do one URF/Co-op per term, and must be on a co-op term or otherwise not taking courses. Note that International Students need a SIN# and work permit to work in Canada. During the term, it is expected that students will be working remotely from a location within Canada. 
 
The Cheriton School of Computer Science is the largest academic concentration of Computer Science researchers in Canada. With over 100 faculty members, 4,000 undergraduate students and 400 graduate students, the School is part of the Faculty of Mathematics and recently earned first place in the Maclean's 2021 university rankings.
Job Responsibilities:
1. Learn the research methodology related to a particular field of interest (see available research areas here: http://grec.cs.uwaterloo.ca). 

2. Review existing literature and develop new research questions. 

3. Work with supervisor and a team of graduate students to address the research questions, which may involve developing systems, creating algorithms, solving mathematical problems, designing experiments, etc. 

4. Participate in regular meetings with an advisor to discuss research ideas and project status.  

5. Work on publications to disseminate research findings to relevant academic conferences.
Required Skills:
EDUCATION 
- Current undergraduate 3rd or 4th year student in a Computer Science program (or related degree)  
- Cumulative average of 80% or higher  
- Interest in research and/or graduate studies 
 
EXPERIENCE 
Previous research experience is an asset, but not required
